p: M. hominis surface-localized lipoprotein OppA, the substrate-binding domain of the oligopeptide permease, has been characterized as an ecto-ATPase [ 102, 244]. OppA induces ATP-release from HeLa cells; subsequently, the discharged ATP is hydrolyzed by its intrinsic ATPase activity that ultimately results in apoptosis of the host cells [ 245]. Moreover, the cytadhesion of M. hominis also depends on the ecto-ATPase activity of OppA [ 246]. These results demonstrate that OppA affects not only nutrition uptake but also the host-pathogen interactions of M. hominis. Two OppA-coding genes were also identified in the genome of Mccp strain 87,001, but their functions remain unidentified [ 232]. M. gallisepticum possesses the MGA_0220 gene that encodes a putative ATP-binding protein (OppD), which is involved in amino acid, dipeptide, and oligopeptide transport. OppD is required for pathogenesis as the mutant strain has been shown to have a reduced capacity to induce respiratory tract lesions and persist in the respiratory tract, but its ATPase activity remains to be investigated [ 13, 247, 248].
